questions.solution:
• AIR EMBOLISM:- Gas bubbles within the circulation can coalesce to form Frothy masses that obstruct vascular flow and cause distal ischemic injury
  • A particular form of gas embolism, called decompression sickness, occurs when individuals experience sudden.
  • CAISSON DISEASE → A more chronic form of decompression sickness (choice C)
  • Named for the pressurized vessels used in bridge construction; workers in these vessels suffered both acute and chronic forms of decompression sickness
  • Persistence of gas emboli in the skeletal system leads to multiple foci of ischemic necrosis (choice D)
  • the more common sites are the femoral heads, tibia, and humeri. (Choice B)
  • Choice A suggests the fat embolism.

Key Takeaways: Caisson disease is a chronic form of decompression sickness, where gas emboli cause ischemic necrosis, often in the femoral head, tibia, and humerus. It differs from fat embolism, which involves microscopic fat globules.

questions.text: Neurogenic shock and septic shock both are characterized by all of the following, EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock and septic shock both are characterized by:-

  • Vasodilation
  • Warm extremities
  • Decreased total peripheral resistance

Neurogenic shock → bradycardia, decreased cardiac output

Septic shock → tachycardia, normal to increased cardiac output

Key Takeaways: Neurogenic and septic shock are characterized by vasodilation, warm extremities, and decreased total peripheral resistance. However, polyuria is not typically associated with these types of shock. Neurogenic shock is marked by bradycardia and decreased cardiac output, while septic shock often features tachycardia and normal to increased cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a platelet aggregator?
questions.solution:
Platelet aggregators:-

  • ADP
  • Epinephrine
  • vWF
  • Thrombospondin
  • TxA2
  • Immune complex
  • Serotonin
  • Fibrinogen
  • Collagen
  • Thrombin

Platelet antiaggregators:-

  • PGI2
  • Endothelin
  • NO
  • Bradykinin

Key Takeaways:

  • Platelet aggregators include substances like ADP, epinephrine, vWF, collagen, and thrombin
  • PGI2, endothelin, NO, and bradykinin act as antiaggregators, inhibiting platelet aggregation.

questions.text: Proteins which are recognized by antiphospholipid autoantibodies are?
questions.solution:
Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS)

  • APS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by: (CLINICAL CRITERIA)
  • Presence of one or more antiphospholipid (aPL) autoantibodies
  • Venous or arterial thromboses, or pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, unexplained fetal death, and premature birth
  • Laboratory criteria:-
  • IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies
  • IgG or IgM anti beta 2 glycoprotein I antibody
  • Lupus anticoagulant positivity
  • Proteins that are recognized by these antibodies include cardiolipin and β2-glycoprotein I.

Key Takeaways: Antiphospholipid autoantibodies recognize cardiolipin, beta 2 glycoprotein I, and lupus anticoagulant. These proteins are associated with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS), an autoimmune disorder linked to thromboses and pregnancy complications.

choices.text: Dark-red dependent portion show red cells settle by gravity

questions.text: Wrong about post mortem clot from the following is?
questions.solution:
• Can be mistaken for antemortem venous thrombi
  • Clots formed after death are gelatinous (choice A)
  • They have dark red dependent portion where red cells have settled by gravity (choice C) and a yellow 'chicken fat' upper portion (choice D)
  • Not usually attached to the underlying vessel wall. (Choice B)

Key Takeaways: Post-mortem clots are gelatinous, with a dark-red dependent portion where red cells settle by gravity and a yellow "chicken fat" upper portion. They are not attached to the underlying vessel wall, which distinguishes them from antemortem venous thrombi.

choices.text: Grows in antegrade direction towards heart

questions.solution: Key Takeaways: Arterial thrombi cause incomplete obstruction, form in rapidly flowing blood, and propagate retrogradely. They consist of white thrombi (platelets and RBCs).

questions.text: Immediate hemostasis, following injury to a blood vessel is achieved by?
questions.solution:
The general sequence of events leading to Hemostasis at a site of vascular injury 

  • Arteriolar vasoconstriction occurs immediately (choice C) and markedly reduces blood flow to the injured area.
  • Primary hemostasis: the formation of the platelet plug.
  • Disruption of the endothelium exposes subendothelial von Willebrand factor (vWF) and collagen, which promote platelet adherence and activation.
  • Within a few minutes, the secreted products recruit additional platelets that undergo aggregation to form a primary hemostatic plug
  • Secondary hemostasis: deposition of fibrin.
  • Local activation of the coagulation cascade (involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids) results in fibrin polymerization, 'cementing' the platelets into a definitive secondary hemostatic plug.
  • Counterregulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.

Key Takeaways: Immediate hemostasis following blood vessel injury is achieved by vasoconstriction, which reduces blood flow. This is followed by platelet adhesion and fibrin deposition to form a stable clot.

questions.text: The prothrombin time assays the function of which proteins in extrinsic pathway?
questions.solution:
• Prothrombin time (PT) is used to assess the function of the extrinsic pathway (which involves Factor VII) and the common pathway (involving Factor X, Factor V, prothrombin (Factor II), and fibrinogen). PT primarily measures the activity of Factor VII in the extrinsic pathway and Factor X in the common pathway.
  • Factor X is critical in the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, which is a key step in clot formation.

Explanation for incorrect answers:-

  • b) Factor XII: This factor is part of the intrinsic pathway, not the extrinsic pathway. PT does not assess the intrinsic pathway.
  • c) Factor II: Although PT involves Factor II (prothrombin) in the common pathway, it is not the primary factor assessed by PT for the extrinsic pathway.
  • d) Fibrinogen: PT assesses fibrinogen indirectly as part of the clotting cascade, but it is not the primary factor in the extrinsic pathway.

Key Takeaways: Prothrombin time primarily assesses the extrinsic pathway (Factor VII) and the common pathway (Factor X, Factor V, prothrombin, and fibrinogen). It helps evaluate clotting disorders and monitor warfarin therapy.

questions.text: Choose the correct sites of arterial thrombi in decreasing order of frequency from the following.
questions.solution:
Arterial thrombi :-

  • Frequently occlusive
  • Three most common Sites in decreasing order of frequency coronary > cerebral > femoral arteries.
  • They typically consist of a friable meshwork of platelets, fibrin, red cells, and degenerating leukocytes.
  • These are usually superimposed on a ruptured atherosclerotic plaque, other vascular injuries (vasculitis, trauma) may be the underlying cause.

Key Takeaways: Arterial thrombi most commonly occur in the coronary, cerebral, and femoral arteries in that order. These thrombi are often occlusive and composed of platelets, fibrin, red cells, and leukocytes. They usually form on ruptured atherosclerotic plaques but can also result from vascular injuries like vasculitis or trauma.

questions.text: A 28 years old female came with complains of chronic headache, weakness and rash over body since few weeks. She has swollen tender knee joints. She also gave history of two miscarriages earlier. On laboratory examination, thrombocytopenia was noticed consistently in last few months. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APS)

  • APS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by: (CLINICAL CRITERIA)
  • Presence of one or more antiphospholipid (aPL) autoantibodies
  • Venous or arterial thromboses, or pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, unexplained fetal death, and premature birth
  • Laboratory criteria:-
  • IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies
  • IgG or IgM anti beta 2 glycoprotein I antibody
  • Lupus anticoagulant positivity
  • Proteins that are recognized by these antibodies include cardiolipin and β2-glycoprotein I.

Key Takeaways: APS is characterized by thrombocytopenia, recurrent miscarriages, and thrombosis. Laboratory criteria include positive anticardiolipin antibodies, anti-beta 2 glycoprotein I antibodies, and lupus anticoagulant. Symptoms like chronic headache, weakness, rash, swollen joints, and pregnancy complications support this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic finding of severe renal disease?
questions.solution:
• Edema resulting from renal dysfunction often appears initially In parts of the body containing loose connective tissue, such as the eyelids; periorbital edema is thus a characteristic finding in severe renal disease. (Choice B)
  • Pulmonary edema → the lungs are often two to three times their normal weight, and sectioning yields frothy, blood-tinged fluid-a mixture of air, edema, and extravasated red cells.
  • Brain edema → can be localized or generalized depending on the nature and extent of the pathologic process or injury.
  • Narrowed sulci and distended gyri, which are compressed by the unyielding skull

Key Takeaways: Periorbital edema is a characteristic finding in severe renal disease, as edema typically first appears in areas with loose connective tissue, like the eyelids. Pulmonary and brain edema are more generalized findings in other conditions.

questions.text: All are the microscopic features of nutmeg liver, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Chronic venous congestion of liver (CVC Liver)

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion, the centrilobular regions are grossly redbrown and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (NUTMEG LIVER) (shown in the image A)
  • Microscopic features (shown in the image B)
  • Centrilobular congestion and hemorrhage
  • Hemosiderin-laden macrophages
  • Hepatocyte dropout and necrosis
  • In acute hepatic congestion, the central vein and sinusoids are distended. Because the centrilobular area is at the distal end of the hepatic blood supply, centrilobular hepatocytes may undergo ischemic necrosis, and the periportal hepatocytes-better oxygenated because of proximity to hepatic arterioles-may only develop fatty change.
  • Mallory hyaline is seen in alcoholic liver cirrhosis, not in cvc liver. (Choice C)

Key Takeaways: Nutmeg liver is characterized by centrilobular congestion, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and hepatocyte dropout and necrosis. Mallory hyaline, however, is associated with alcoholic liver cirrhosis, not chronic venous congestion of the liver.

questions.text: Incorrect about etiologic factor of systemic oedema in multiple organ failure?
questions.solution:
• Reduced albumin synthesis occurs mainly in severe liver diseases and protein malnutrition
  • An important cause of albumin loss is the NEPHROTIC SYNDROME, in which albumin leaks into the urine through abnormally permeable glomerular capillaries.
  • Regardless of cause, reduced plasma osmotic pressure → edema → reduced intravascular volume → renal hypoperfusion → secondary hyperaldosteronism

Key Takeaways: Nephritic syndrome does not typically cause systemic edema in multiple organ failure, as it is characterized by inflammation and glomerular injury, not albumin loss. In contrast, nephrotic syndrome leads to albumin loss, which contributes to edema through reduced plasma osmotic pressure.
